column4: I would like to install the 2.6.24-16 kernel from the command line. Can someone please tell me what command I would use to install the kernel and all the packages associated with that kernel?
sudo apt-cache search 2.6.24-16
why 16?
Well, I'm having problems with the 19 version it seems ("kernel panic"), so I would like to go back to the 16 version.
sudo apt-cache search 2.6.24.16

Thanks, but that returns about 4 screen fulls worth of packages, including debug packages that I assume I don't need. Is there some "apt-get install ..." command for one of those particular packages that will install all the kernel stuff I need? Or do I need to manually install a bunch of packages separately?
depends on your arch and if you need the restricted drivers or not etc.
Do you happen to know the command to list a given package that is installed? e.g. if I want to find out which version of libglib I have installed, what is the command?
--version
oh a library, then you need apt-cache policy nameofpackage
if its a binary, just command --version
But what if I don't know the exact name of the package? Doing "apt-cache policy libglib" does not return anything (I'm pretty sure I have it installed).
tab it
after libglib hit tab <sometimes twice> youll see the list
Hmm... tabbing it doesn't work. Isn't there some way simply search through all my installed package names for a string? ("libglib")
apt-cache search
and it does work, trust me.
I thought that command was to search through available packages, not installed packages--is that not true?
I told you to use policy it does work
apt-cache policy libglib<tab><or_twice> you'll see a list of installed libglib*
choose the one you want and it will tell you the installed version

Yes, thanks, that's exactly what I tried and it doesn't return anything (and also for any other packages I try). I'm in recovery mode in the console--I wouldn't think that would make a difference, but is that my problem with tabbing?
